choices.C: As soon as Phone_A presses the Transfer button for the first time, Phone_B hears the MOH and the MOH audio is chosen from Phone_B User Hold MOH Audio Source settings.
choices.B: Phone_B sends a SIP-REFER message to the Cisco Unified CM with Phone_C information in the Refer-To section.
choices.D: As soon as Phone_A presses the Transfer button for the first time, Phone_B hears the music on hold and the MOH audio is chosen from Phone_A Network Hold MOH Audio Source settings.
choices.E: As soon as Phone_A presses the Transfer button for the first time, Phone_B hears the MOH and the MOH audio is chosen from Phone_A User Hold MOH Audio Source settings.
choices.A: Phone_A sends a SIP-REFER message to the Cisco Unified Communications Manager with Phone_C information in the Refer-To section.

discussion.content: Answer - A & D

Answer should be A & E.
E because it's user who initiated call transfer and not the other device in the network

A & D
User hold: With a user hold, a user presses the Hold button on a phone to explicitly place the caller on hold. If Phone A and Phone B are having a conversation, and the user of Phone B presses the Hold button, Phone B’s user hold source is streamed to Phone A.
■ Network hold: A network hold occurs when a call is placed on hold as part of the
processing of a supplementary service, such as park, transfer, or conference. If Phone
B presses the Transfer button to transfer a call, Phone A still gets placed on hold
but hears Phone B’s network audio source while the rest of the transfer operations
complete.

Network hold includes transfer, conference, call park, and so forth.
I think it's A / D

The User Hold MoH Audio Source configured for the holder determines the audio file that will be streamed when the holder puts a call on hold, and the holdee's configured MRGL indicates the resource or server from which the holdee will receive the MoH stream.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. In an active SIP call between phone user A and phone user B, phone A initiates a call transfer to phone user C. Which two scenarios are correct? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Go to the SIP profile assigned to these IP phones in Cisco Unified CM and change the range of media ports to 16384-32767
choices.B: Ask the firewall administrator to change the ports to TCP.
choices.D: Go to the SIP profile assigned to these IP phones in Cisco Unified CM and change the range of media ports to 20000-22000.
choices.C: Ask the firewall administrator to change the range of UDP ports to 16384-32767.
choices.E: Go to System Parameters in Cisco Unified Communications Manager and change the range of media ports to 20000-22000.

questions.question_text: Cisco SIP IP telephony is implemented on two floors of your company. Afterward, users report intermittent voice issues in calls established between floors. All calls are established, and sometimes they work well, but sometimes there is one-way audio or no audio. You determine that there is a firewall between the floors, and the administrator reports that it is allowing SIP signaling and UDP ports from 20000 to 22000 bidirectionally. What are two possible solutions? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer is C,D

comments.content:
I agree, you either change CUCM to match the firewall or change the firewall to match CUCM.
C and D

discussion.content: This question is tricky because it's asking for two separate solutions. The wording suggests that it's not looking for two tasks to become one single solution. In this case, one solution is to change the ports on the SIP profile of the phones to match the ports on the firewall. The other solution is to ask the firewall admin to change his ports to match the ports in UCM.

Both FW and sip profiles must have the same port, so A and C is the correct answer 
If we need an answer, just D is fine
C and D are the answers. Mert,kerna is correct, they are looking for a single solution. Either change the FW or change the SIP Profile.

Selected Answer: CD
C and D

If you change the ports on the CUCM for the devices to use different ones they need to match the ones that can be used on the firewall so A) is wrong and D) is correct.

discussion.content: It is correct, A and C. Both must be 16384 - 32767. No need to configure 16384 - 32767 in the firewall but 20000 - 22000 in CM. They should be the same.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Service Parameters is where you can set the Reversion Time
D is the answer. Sure you can add a Softkey Template to ensure the Park key is there but, the timer for reversion is configured in service parameters.

Selected Answer: D
Cisco CallManager provides two clusterwide service parameters for call park: Call Park Display Timer and Call Park Reversion Timer. Each service parameter includes a default and requires no special configuration.

- Call Park Display Timer - Default specifies 10 seconds. This parameter determines how long a call park number displays on the phone that parked the call. Set this timer for each server in a cluster that has the Cisco CallManager service and call park configured.

- Call Park Reversion Timer - Default specifies 60 seconds. This parameter determines the time that a call remains parked. Set this timer for each server in a cluster that has the Cisco CallManager service and call park configured. When this timer expires, the parked call returns to the device that parked the call.

https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/4_0_1/ccmfeat/fscallpk.html#wp1027525

questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring Cisco UCM to forward parked calls back to the user who parked the call if it is not retrieved after a specified time interval. Which action must be taken to accomplish this task?

choices.C: Assign the uploaded audio file to the hunting Line Group member’s “User Hold MOH Audio Source”.
choices.A: Assign the uploaded audio file to “Network Hold MOH Source & Announcements” under Hunt Pilot’s Queuing section.
choices.B: Upload the audio file in “TFTP File Management” via OS Administration GUI.
choices.E: Upload the audio file in “MOH Audio File Management” via CM Administration GUI.
choices.D: Assign the uploaded audio file to the hunting Line Group member’s “Network Hold MOH Audio Source”.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
A&E appear to be correct

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure call queuing under a Hunt Pilot. After the engineer receives the audio file that will be played to callers during queuing, which two steps should be taken to complete the configuration? (Choose two.)

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. DN 1003 was the last to ring during the most recent call. Which hunting method ensures that DN 1005 is presented with the next call when the hunt pilot is dialed?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Sequential Hunt Groups—Numbers always ring in the left-to-right order in which they are listed when the hunt group is defined. The first number in the list is always the first number to be tried when the pilot number is called. Maximum number of hops is not a configurable parameter for sequential hunt groups. Sequential hunt Group shows an illustrated example.

Peer Hunt Groups—The first number to ring is the number to the right of the directory number that was the last to ring when the pilot number was last called. Ringing proceeds in a circular manner, left to right, for the number of hops specified in the hunt group configuration. Peer hunt Group shows an illustrated example.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucme/admin/configuration/manual/cmeadm/cmecover.html#concept_84738A1DC1EE4FCD81E16B79CA9CCB47
Answer is C : peer method.

Selected Answer: C
See Peer Hunt Groups:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucme/admin/configuration/manual/cmeadm/cmecover.html#concept_84738A1DC1EE4FCD81E16B79CA9CCB47

Selected Answer: C
